thread.title: Open Doors listings for week of Oct. 24
thread.title_full: Open Doors listings for week of Oct. 24

author: Jan Flanagan Journal staff
title: Open Doors listings for week of Oct. 24
text: Open Doors listings for week of Oct. 24 Tours, classes and other events related to house and garden in and around R.I. Comment Journal staff Posted Oct. 24, 2015 @ 12:01 am LECTURES/WORKSHOPS Dan Snydacker, former director of the Newport Historical Society, lectures on "Lippitt's Castles: Governor Charles W. Lippitt Patron of Rhode Island Architecture" Tuesday, Oct. 27, at 7 p.m. at Lippitt House Museum, 199 Hope St., Providence. The free talk will focus on Lippitt's involvement in the design of the Rhode Island State House and Lippitt's Castle in Newport. The lecture is preceded by a reception at 6:30 p.m. preserveri.org . The Somerset Garden Club hosts a program, "Inspire by J. Marie," presented by Joanne Robidoux at its meeting Wednesday, Oct. 28, at 6:30 p.m., in the activity room of Clifton Assisted Living, 44 Wilbur Ave., Somerset. Robidoux will demonstrate how she creates terrariums with plant materials she finds in local woods and meadows. The program is free. Several finished terrariums will be available for purchase and one will be a drawing prize. Light refreshments will be served. The Preservation Society of Newport County hosts a lecture by Lindsy Parrott, director/curator of The Neustadt Collection of Tiffany Glass, on "Tiffany Glass: Painting With Color and Light," Thursday, Oct. 29, at 6 p.m. at Rosecliff, 548 Bellevue Ave., Newport. Admission is $10 and registration is required. 847-1851; newportmansions.org . "Orchid Equipment, Potions and Gadgets" is the topic to be discussed at the next meeting of the Rhode Island Orchid Society on Saturday, Oct. 31, at 10:30 a.m. at the Roger Williams Park Botanical Center, 1000 Elmwood Ave., Providence. Attendees will learn the tricks orchid enthusiasts use and rely upon to produce robust, blooming orchid plants. All are welcome. riorchidsociety.org . OCTOBER BAZAARS 24: International Arts and Crafts Festival, SS. Rose and Clement Parish, 111 Long St., Warwick. 739-0212. Crafters from Ocean State Artisans and others, religious goods, penny social, white elephant, raffle. Parisian-themed bakery, hot turkey sandwiches, breakfast sandwiches, hamburgers, hot dogs, meatball sandwiches, fries, onion rings, German Brats, children's meal deal. 9 a.m.-7 p.m. 739-0212. 24: Bazaar, Holy Rosary Sodality of St. Elizabeth's Church, 577 Wood St., Bristol. Christmas booth with hand-made ornaments, table decorations and wreaths; arts and crafts booth with doilies, baby outfits, hats and mittens, scarves and blankets; knitted and crocheted jewelry; white elephant; attic treasures; country store with jams, jellies, baked beans, fudge, cheese and relishes; plants; hand-painted birdhouses; book nook; religious articles. Kitchen serving Portuguese and other foods. 9 a.m.-3 p.m. 24: Craft Fair and Holiday Bazaar, Church of the Transfiguration, 1665 Broad St., Cranston. 467-7434. Crafters, raffle, jewelry, knitted goods, local art, baked goods, penny social, winter thrift sale, lunch available. 8:30 a.m.-3 p.m. 24: Octoberfest Craft Fair, Knights of Columbus Hall, 1675 Douglas Ave., North Providence. eventbrite.com . Crafters, vendors. Hosted by Cherish the Moments.10 a.m.-4 p.m. Free admission, parking. 24: Halloween Bazaar and Indoor Yard Sale, Bridgeton School, 16 Laurel Hill Ave., Pascoag. 568-8449, 500-0433. Halloween penny social, Halloween crafts, artwork, decorations, gifts, homemade treats, indoor yard sale. Chilling tales of Burrillville at 3 p.m. including "The 1832 Hanging of Amasa Walmsley" and "Stabbed with a Hayfork in Glendale Cemetery." Research material available for public viewing. 9 a.m.-3 p.m. CRAFT PROGRAM The Artists' Exchange, 50 Rolfe Square, Cranston, hosts Kiki's Garden Craft Bash Saturday, Oct. 31, from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. The event is free. kikisgarden.org; artists-exchange.org . TOURS/WALKS Hearthside House, 677 Great Rd., Lincoln, hosts its “Gone But Not Forgotten: Victorian Mourning and Funeral Customs” tours Saturday and Sunday, Oct. 24 and 25, featuring docents dressed in mourning attire who explain the customs that families practiced when someone passed. Exhibits and traditional funeral music will fill the house and visitors will be offered special Victorian “funeral cookies.” Objects on view include mourning clothing, jewelry made from the hair of the deceased, black-bordered stationery and post-mortem photographs in which family members pose with the dead loved ones propped up in life-like positions. Antique tools and a portable embalming table will also be on display. There is a candlelight tour Saturday, 4 to 7 p.m., and a daytime tour Sunday, 1 to 4 p.m. Reservations are accepted for the Saturday candlelight tour held on the hour ($10). The daytime Sunday tour is $8. 726-05997; hearthsidehouse.org . The Rhode Island Historical Society presents "What Cheer Day: Go Back in Time to 1803" at the John Brown House Museum, 52 Power St., Providence, Saturday, Oct. 24, 1 to 4 p.m. Costumed interpreters playing the roles of the Brown family and their 18th-century neighbors will be preparing for John Brown's funeral. Visitors will learn about the rituals surrounding death in the late 18th and early 19th century. Tickets for the tour are $15, children 12 and younger are admitted free. Take a free champion trees tour Saturday, Oct. 24 , at Wilcox Park, 44 Broad St., Westerly, with the Southern Rhode Island Master Gardeners. The tour begins with information about the park and the National and Rhode Island Big Tree registries, followed by a walk around the park to see the champions and runners-up. The tour lasts about 90 minutes. Meet at the park fountain. urimastergardeners.org/southern-ri . SHOW Lyman Estate Greenhouses, 185 Lyman St., Waltham, Mass., is having its fall orchid sale Saturday and Sunday, Oct. 24 and 25, 9:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. The sale features hundreds of orchid plants including many hard-to-find varieties. The mansion will be open for tours Saturday, Oct. 24, with tours at 10 a.m., 11 a.m. and noon. historicnewengland.org . EXHIBIT "Staging of Freedom: Black Performing Arts in Rhode Island," a new exhibit on view at the Providence Public Library, will explore the contributions black artists have made to the performing arts, specifically on stage and screen, in Rhode Island. It will include photographs, costumes and memorabilia related to black theater, dance and music. The exhibit may be seen during regular library hours through December in the library's Grand Hall, 150 Empire St., Providence. 487-6173; provlib.org . SALES Friends of the Fall River Public Library's book sale continues Saturday, Oct. 24, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., in the library's bookstore on the upper level of the main library, 104 North Main St., Fall River. All proceeds benefit the library. (508) 324-2700. The Friends of Rochambeau Library's book sale continues Saturday, Oct. 24, starting at 10 a.m. at the Rochambeau Library, 709 Hope St., Providence. Most books are $1 or 50 cents for small paperbacks or children's items. Rare and special books are priced separately and there is a special "Fill-A-Bag-For-$5" (library provide the bags). friendsofrochambeau.org . Westminster Unitarian Church's used clothing sale takes place Saturday, Oct. 24, 9 a.m. to noon, at the church, 119 Kenyon Ave., East Greenwich. Men's, women's and children's clothes, linens, jewelry and household items will be for sale. 884-5933. The Friends of the Pawtucket Library is having a fall book sale Saturday, Oct. 24, 9 a.m. to 3 p.m., in the library's Campbell Auditorium, 13 Summer St., Pawtucket. Paperback books will sell for 25 cents or five for $1; hardcover books, CDs, DVDs and audio books will sell for 50 cents. 725-3714. The Friends of Newport Public Library will hold a holiday book sale in the library's Spring Street lobby starting Saturday, Oct. 24, and continuing through Wednesday, Oct. 28. Proceeds will help update the library's reference section and support library programs. The library is at 300 Spring St., Newport. Sale hours are Saturday 9:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., Sunday 1 to 4:30 p.m., Monday 1 to 7 p.m., and Tuesday and Wednesday, 9:30 a.m. to 7 p.m. 847-8720. Sail Newport hosts a community boatyard sale Saturday, Oct. 24, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m., and Sunday, 9 a.m. to noon, at Fort Adams State Park at the Mule Barn, Newport. Boats, hardware, gear, sails, blades, clothing, charts and nautical home decor will be for sale. Proceeds benefit Sail Newport's Sailing Center. 846-1983; sailnewport.org . ETC. Kenyon's Grist Mill, 21 Glen Rock Road, West Kingston, offers free mill tours with jonnycake demonstrations Saturday and Sunday, Oct. 24 and 25, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Guests can sample free jonnycakes and local coffee. Kenyon's products and local items, as well as clam cakes and chowder will be for sale. Admission and parking are free. 783-4054 kenyonsgristmill.com . West Bay Opens Studios will take place Saturday and Sunday, Oct. 24 and 25, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Tour-goers will have the opportunity to meet the artists in their working environment, view the artistic process and purchase original art. The free self-guided tour is of studios in East Greenwich, Warwick, Exeter, North Kingstown, Saunderstown. westbayopenstudios.com . A Rhode Island White Cap Flint Corn Harvest Celebration takes place in South Kingstown this weekend. Speakers will talk about flint corn, the Samuel E. Perry Grist Mill and jonnycakes; Nancy Brown Garcia, a member of the Narragansett Indian tribe, discusses "Traditional Uses of Corn" and jonnycake samples will be served, all at South Kingstown Land Trust Barn, 17 Matunuck Beach Rd., South Kingstown, Saturday, Oct. 24, from 2 to 4 p.m. (donations accepted). On Sunday, Oct. 25, beginning at 2 p.m., grinding demonstrations will be presented at the Samuel E. Perry Grist Mill, 364 Moonstone Beach Rd., Perryville. 783-5483. The Arts & Cultural Alliance of Newport County host a glass blowing demonstration by a skilled glassblower at Thames Glass, 688 Thames St., Newport, Thursday, Oct. 29, at 4 p.m. (arrive by 3:45 p.m.) The cost is $10 and reservations are required. Glass blowing lessons to make your own ornament or paper weight for Christmas will be available after the demonstration. The program is part of the alliance's "Arts Behind the Scenes" series. Reservations are required. 862-0083; newportarts.org . The Art League of Rhode Island celebrates Halloween with Tinker Time with Artists Saturday, Oct. 31, from 1 to 3 p.m., at The Vets Gallery, Veterans Memorial Auditorium, 5th floor, 83 Park St, Providence. The free hands-on STEAM workshop (Science, Technology, Engineering, Art and Design and Math) is for ages 7 and older (children must be accompanied by an adult). Participants will explore physical phenomena through observing, touching and making alongside artists and designers and can visualize mathematical structures, build a smart sculpture, construct a magical moving image or create a nature-inspired collage. Participating artists and designers include Carl Fasano, John Arden Hiigli, Amy Leidtke, Stephen Metcalf, Wanda M. Miglus, Sophia Sobers and others. 861-0500; office@artleagueri.org . ENVIRONMENT The documentary "Groundswell Rising" will be shown Monday, Oct. 26, at 7 p.m. at Emmanuel Church, 42 Dearborn St., Newport. The film features interviews with families living on the Marcellus Shale region in Pennsylvania near environmentally sensitive lands. Three major natural gas installations planned for Rhode Island would be dependent on gas piped from that area. An open discussion will take place after the screening. Admission and parking are free. 847-0675; rector@emmanuelnewport.org . The Audubon Environmental Education Center, 1401 Hope St., Bristol, offers eco-stories and art for all ages Saturday, Oct. 24, 11 a.m. to noon. An Audubon naturalist will read a nature story and visitors can create a work of art from different recyclable materials and found articles. The cost is $3 for materials plus admission ($6, children 4-12 $4, children 3 and younger/ASRI members free). 949-5454; asri.org . The Rhode Island Resource Recovery Corporation hosts Eco-Depot at the Department of Public Works, 2050 Davisville Rd., North Kingstown, Saturday, Oct. 24, and at the Melrose School, 76 Melrose Ave., Jamestown, Saturday, Oct. 31, both from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m. Eco-Depot is a free service that allows for proper handling, packaging, storing, transportation and disposal of household hazardous waste. The collection is free to Rhode Island residents. Make an appointment to help reduce time spent in line. 942-1430, ext. 241; rirrc.org . To submit items to Open Doors, email features@providencejournal.com ; be sure to put Open Doors in the subject field. You can also mail items to Features Department, The Providence Journal, 75 Fountain St., Providence RI 02902. Deadline for submissions is three weeks before the date of publication.
